articles.headline: California’s Zigzag on Welfare Rules Worries Experts
articles.snippet: The state is embracing a startling reversal in some of its welfare policies that reflects the recession and the state’s financial crisis.
articles.abstract: The state is embracing a startling reversal in some of its welfare policies that reflects the recession and the state’s financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRESNO, Calif.  As he pressed state lawmakers over the summer to close a record budget deficit, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger lathered scorn on the state’s welfare-to-work program. He called it too lenient on the work requirement and overly generous in its benefits. At one point, he proposed eliminating it, then compromised to make it tougher.

articles.headline: Obama Rules Out Large Reduction in Afghan Force
articles.snippet: President Obama seemed to be searching for a middle ground as he indicated that he remained undecided about a buildup of U.S. forces in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: President Obama seemed to be searching for a middle ground as he indicated that he remained undecided about a buildup of U.S. forces in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama told Congressional leaders on Tuesday that he would not substantially reduce American forces in Afghanistan or shift the mission to just hunting terrorists there, but he indicated that he remained undecided about the major troop buildup proposed by his commanding general.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Jeff Zeleny

articles.headline: Debt-Market Paralysis Deepens Credit Drought
articles.snippet: Asset-backed securities used to be the grease that kept the credit markets rolling smoothly. Now the government props up that market, and it’s planning to cut back.
articles.abstract: Asset-backed securities used to be the grease that kept the credit markets rolling smoothly. Now the government props up that market, and it’s planning to cut back.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year after Washington rescued the big names of American finance, it’s still hard to get a loan. But the problem isn’t just tight-fisted banks.

articles.headline: In E-Books, It’s an Army vs. Google
articles.snippet: A broad array of authors, academics, librarians and public interest groups are fighting Google’s plan to create a huge digital library and bookstore.
articles.abstract: A broad array of authors, academics, librarians and public interest groups are fighting Google’s plan to create a huge digital library and bookstore.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  Whenever it can, Google likes to have programmers solve its problems. But now it faces a dispute that even its ranks of lawyers and lobbyists are finding hard to smooth over.

articles.headline: Partisan Economics in Action
articles.snippet: Bruce Bartlett, who worked for two Republican presidents, raises a concern that the G.O.P. no longer has a credible economic policy.
articles.abstract: Bruce Bartlett, who worked for two Republican presidents, raises a concern that the G.O.P. no longer has a credible economic policy.

articles.headline: More Ads for Basic Brands as Shoppers Spend Less
articles.snippet: Advertising for common food items like General Mills cereals and Jif peanut butter is holding steady and in many cases increasing.
articles.abstract: Advertising for common food items like General Mills cereals and Jif peanut butter is holding steady and in many cases increasing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Readers of this week’s People magazine could be excused for believing they were leafing through a Look magazine from 1959. Of the 44 full-page ads in the issue, half are for brands like Campbell’s, Jell-O, Kraft cheese, Lipton tea and Post cereal.

articles.headline: Support Is Building for a Tax Credit to Help Hiring
articles.snippet: The idea of a tax credit for companies that create new jobs, which the federal government has not tried since the 1970s, is gaining support among economists and Washington officials.
articles.abstract: The idea of a tax credit for companies that create new jobs, which the federal government has not tried since the 1970s, is gaining support among economists and Washington officials.
articles.lead_paragraph: The idea of a tax credit for companies that create new jobs, something the federal government has not tried since the 1970s, is gaining support among economists and Washington officials grappling with the highest unemployment in a generation.

articles.headline: Regulators Plan to Study Risks of Atrazine
articles.snippet: New studies linking atrazine in drinking water with birth defects, low birth weights and reproductive problems in humans have prompted the E.P.A. to study its effects.
articles.abstract: New studies linking atrazine in drinking water with birth defects, low birth weights and reproductive problems in humans have prompted the E.P.A. to study its effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Environmental Protection Agency plans to conduct a new study about the potential health risks of atrazine, a widely used weedkiller that recent research suggests may be more dangerous to humans than previously thought.
